title: Formal Units of Measurement
description: Measure length, mass and capacity using standard units (cm, m, kg, L)
objectives: Measure length using centimetres (cm) and metres (m)
Measure mass using grams (g) and kilograms (kg)
Measure capacity using millilitres (mL) and litres (L)

sections.title: Measuring with Standard Units
sections.content:
Remember measuring with paper clips and hand spans? Those are informal units. Now it's time to learn **standard (formal) units** -- the units that everyone around the world agrees on!

In Australia, we use the **metric system**. Let's explore the units for length, mass and capacity.

sections.title: Measuring Length
sections.content:
We measure how long things are using:

| Unit | Symbol | Used for |
|------|--------|----------|
| **Centimetre** | cm | Small things (pencils, books) |
| **Metre** | m | Bigger things (rooms, buildings) |
| **Kilometre** | km | Very long distances (between towns) |

**Key conversion:** $1 \text{ m} = 100 \text{ cm}$

**Benchmarks to remember:**
- Your fingernail is about $1 \text{ cm}$ wide
- A ruler is $30 \text{ cm}$ long
- A door is about $2 \text{ m}$ tall
- $1 \text{ km}$ is about a 15-minute walk

**Using a ruler:** Line up the object with the **0 mark** (not the edge!). Read the number where the object ends.

sections.title: Measuring Mass and Capacity
sections.content:
**Mass** (how heavy something is):

| Unit | Symbol | Used for |
|------|--------|----------|
| **Gram** | g | Light things (a paperclip is about 1 g) |
| **Kilogram** | kg | Heavier things (a bag of sugar is 1 kg) |

$$1 \text{ kg} = 1000 \text{ g}$$

**Capacity** (how much a container holds):

| Unit | Symbol | Used for |
|------|--------|----------|
| **Millilitre** | mL | Small amounts (a teaspoon is about 5 mL) |
| **Litre** | L | Larger amounts (a milk carton is 1 L) |

$$1 \text{ L} = 1000 \text{ mL}$$

**Benchmarks:**
- A loaf of bread is about $500 \text{ g}$
- A bag of potatoes is about $2 \text{ kg}$
- A small water bottle is $600 \text{ mL}$
- A large milk bottle is $2 \text{ L}$

sections.title: Example: Choosing the Right Unit
sections.content: What unit would you use to measure the length of a cricket pitch?
steps: A cricket pitch is quite long -- too long for centimetres but not as far as between towns
Centimetres: too small (you'd get a very big number)
Kilometres: too big (a cricket pitch is much less than 1 km)
A cricket pitch is about $20 \text{ m}$ long

sections.title: Converting Between Units
sections.content:
To convert between units:

**Going from big to small: MULTIPLY**
- $3 \text{ m} = 3 \times 100 = 300 \text{ cm}$
- $2 \text{ kg} = 2 \times 1000 = 2000 \text{ g}$
- $5 \text{ L} = 5 \times 1000 = 5000 \text{ mL}$

**Going from small to big: DIVIDE**
- $500 \text{ cm} = 500 \div 100 = 5 \text{ m}$
- $4000 \text{ g} = 4000 \div 1000 = 4 \text{ kg}$
- $3000 \text{ mL} = 3000 \div 1000 = 3 \text{ L}$

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Great measuring! In this lesson you learned:

- **Length:** cm, m, km ($1 \text{ m} = 100 \text{ cm}$)
- **Mass:** g, kg ($1 \text{ kg} = 1000 \text{ g}$)
- **Capacity:** mL, L ($1 \text{ L} = 1000 \text{ mL}$)
- Choose the right unit based on what you're measuring
- **Multiply** to go from big to small units; **divide** to go the other way

Practise estimating before you measure -- it helps develop your sense of measurement!

workedExamples.title: Converting Metres to Centimetres
workedExamples.problem: A table is 2 m long. How many centimetres is that?
steps: Going from big (m) to small (cm): multiply
workedExamples.explanation: Since there are 100 centimetres in every metre, we multiply the number of metres by 100.

workedExamples.title: Choosing the Right Unit
workedExamples.problem: Which unit would you use: the mass of a strawberry, or the mass of a car?
steps: A strawberry is very light: use **grams (g)** (about 10-20 g)
A car is very heavy: use **kilograms (kg)** (about 1000-2000 kg)
Using grams for a car would give a huge number
Using kilograms for a strawberry would give a tiny decimal
workedExamples.explanation: Choose the unit that gives a sensible number. Grams for light objects, kilograms for heavy ones.

title: Telling Time and Calculating Elapsed Time
description: Tell time to the minute and calculate how much time has passed
objectives: Tell time to the nearest minute on an analogue clock
Convert between analogue and digital time formats
Calculate elapsed time (how long between two events)

sections.title: Time to the Minute!
sections.content: You already know o'clock, half-past and quarter times. Now let's read the clock **to the exact minute** and learn to work out how much time has passed between two events.

sections.title: Reading Minutes on a Clock
sections.content:
The clock face has **60 minutes** in total. Each small mark on the clock = 1 minute.

The **minute hand** moves around the clock:
- At the **12**: 0 minutes (o'clock)
- At the **1**: 5 minutes
- At the **2**: 10 minutes
- At the **3**: 15 minutes (quarter-past)
- At the **6**: 30 minutes (half-past)
- At the **9**: 45 minutes (quarter-to)

**Reading any time:**
1. Look at the **hour hand** -- which number has it passed?
2. Count the **minutes** from 12 using the minute hand

**Example:** Hour hand just past 8, minute hand on the 4th small mark after 2.
- Hour: 8
- Minutes: $10 + 4 = 14$
- Time: **8:14**

sections.title: Calculating Elapsed Time
sections.content:
**Elapsed time** is the amount of time that passes between two events.

**Method: Count on from the start time to the end time.**

**Example:** A movie starts at 2:15 and ends at 4:00. How long is the movie?

- From 2:15 to 3:00 = 45 minutes
- From 3:00 to 4:00 = 1 hour = 60 minutes
- Total: $45 + 60 = 105$ minutes = **1 hour and 45 minutes**

**Remember:**
- $1 \text{ hour} = 60 \text{ minutes}$
- $1 \text{ day} = 24 \text{ hours}$
- $1 \text{ week} = 7 \text{ days}$

When calculating elapsed time, you can use a **number line** to jump from the start time to the end time.

sections.title: Example: How Long Did It Take?
sections.content: Ella started her homework at 4:30 and finished at 5:15. How long did she spend on homework?

sections.title: AM and PM
sections.content:
A day has **24 hours**, but our clocks only show 12. That's why we use **AM** and **PM**:

- **AM** = midnight to noon (morning hours)
- **PM** = noon to midnight (afternoon and evening hours)

**Timeline of a day:**
- $12:00 \text{ AM}$ = midnight (start of a new day)
- $7:30 \text{ AM}$ = morning
- $12:00 \text{ PM}$ = noon (midday)
- $3:00 \text{ PM}$ = afternoon
- $8:00 \text{ PM}$ = evening
- $11:59 \text{ PM}$ = just before midnight

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
You're a time master! In this lesson you learned:

- Read time **to the minute** on an analogue clock
- Each number on the clock represents **5 minutes**
- **Elapsed time** = how much time passes between two events
- Count on from start to end to find elapsed time
- **AM** is for morning, **PM** is for afternoon/evening

Practise by timing everyday activities -- how long does it take to eat breakfast?

workedExamples.title: Reading a Clock to the Minute
workedExamples.problem: The hour hand has just passed 10 and the minute hand points to the 7. What time is it?
steps: Hour hand past 10 → the hour is 10
workedExamples.explanation: Each number on the clock face represents 5 minutes. The 7 represents $7 \times 5 = 35$ minutes past the hour.

workedExamples.title: Finding Elapsed Time
workedExamples.problem: A bus leaves at 9:20 AM and arrives at 10:05 AM. How long is the trip?
workedExamples.explanation: We count from 9:20 to the next whole hour (10:00 = 40 minutes), then add the extra 5 minutes.

title: Perimeter
description: Calculate the perimeter of shapes by adding the lengths of all sides
objectives: Understand perimeter as the distance around a shape
Calculate the perimeter of rectangles, squares and triangles

sections.title: Walking Around the Edge!
sections.content:
Imagine an ant walking all the way around the outside of a rectangle. How far does it walk? That distance is called the **perimeter**.

**Perimeter** = the total distance around the outside of a shape. It's like putting a fence around a garden or a frame around a picture.

sections.title: Calculating Perimeter
sections.content:
To find the perimeter, **add up the lengths of all the sides**.

**Triangle** with sides 5 cm, 4 cm and 3 cm:
$$P = 5 + 4 + 3 = 12 \text{ cm}$$

**Rectangle** with length 8 cm and width 3 cm:
A rectangle has 2 long sides and 2 short sides:
$$P = 8 + 3 + 8 + 3 = 22 \text{ cm}$$

Or use the shortcut:
$$P = 2 \times (8 + 3) = 2 \times 11 = 22 \text{ cm}$$

**Square** with sides of 5 cm:
All 4 sides are equal:
$$P = 5 + 5 + 5 + 5 = 4 \times 5 = 20 \text{ cm}$$

sections.title: Example: Perimeter of a Garden
sections.content: A rectangular garden is 10 m long and 6 m wide. What is the perimeter?
steps: Identify the sides: two sides of 10 m and two sides of 6 m

sections.title: Example: Finding a Missing Side
sections.content: A rectangle has a perimeter of 24 cm. The length is 8 cm. What is the width?

sections.title: Perimeter Shortcuts
sections.content:
**Rectangle perimeter formula:**
$$P = 2 \times (\text{length} + \text{width})$$

**Square perimeter formula:**
$$P = 4 \times \text{side length}$$

These shortcuts work because:
- A rectangle has **2 pairs** of equal sides
- A square has **4 equal** sides

For any other shape, just add up all the side lengths!

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Well done! In this lesson you learned:

- **Perimeter** is the distance all the way around a shape
- To find perimeter: **add all the side lengths**
- Rectangle shortcut: $P = 2 \times (l + w)$
- Square shortcut: $P = 4 \times s$
- You can find a **missing side** if you know the perimeter

Measure the perimeter of objects around you -- your book, your desk, or the classroom!

workedExamples.title: Finding a Rectangle's Perimeter
workedExamples.problem: A swimming pool is 25 m long and 10 m wide. What is the perimeter?
workedExamples.solution: The perimeter of the pool is **70 m**.
workedExamples.explanation: A rectangle has two lengths and two widths: $25 + 10 + 25 + 10 = 70 \text{ m}$.

workedExamples.title: Finding a Missing Side Length
workedExamples.problem: A square has a perimeter of 36 cm. What is the length of each side?
workedExamples.explanation: Since all 4 sides of a square are equal, divide the perimeter by 4 to find one side: $36 \div 4 = 9 \text{ cm}$.
